[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of anxiety and uncertainty when it comes to finding a job. It's understandable that the negative experiences and feedback from others have discouraged you. However, it's important to remember that everyone's experiences and opinions are not the same, and it's possible to find a job that aligns with your goals and values.

Given your background in agriculture and your goal of growing and selling your own produce, it might be worth exploring opportunities in that field. You could look for jobs at local farms, farmers markets, or even start your own business. This could provide you with a sense of purpose and fulfillment, while also allowing you to use your skills and knowledge.

Additionally, it might be helpful to focus on the aspects of a job that you enjoy and find fulfilling, rather than solely on the negative aspects. For example, if you enjoy being in the kitchen, you could look for prep cook positions at restaurants or cafes. While the pay and hours may not be ideal, it could provide you with the opportunity to be around food and use your skills in a way that brings you joy.

It's also important to remember that everyone has their own unique strengths and challenges, and it's okay to ask for accommodations or find ways to make a job work for you. For example, if your anxiety makes it difficult for you to remember orders as a waitress, you could ask for a visual schedule or other accommodations to help you stay organized.

Lastly, it's important to remember that finding a job and navigating the workforce can be challenging for anyone, and it's okay to take your time and find a job that feels right for you. It might be helpful to focus on your goals and what you want to achieve, rather than getting caught up in the negative aspects of the job search. Remember, you have the strength and resilience to overcome these challenges and find a job that aligns with your values and goals.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m f currently on a work trip with a few of my coworkers most of whom i ve known for year but haven t seen in person since covid started i m decently close with one person in particular and the rest i just have a normal professional relationship with last night everyone went out to celebrate a big milestone during the trip and had a great time i wa definitely pretty drunk by the end of the night and getting home is a little hazy but i woke up with good memory of the night before and wasn t concerned that anything had happened anyways no one had texted me this morning and i wasn t sure what the plan for the day wa so i reached out to the coworker i m closer with and asked what she wa up to she said she wa going to breakfast with another person on the trip and that i could come which i agreed to but then she texted and said they were actually leaving right now for breakfast and that we could meet up later this seemed odd to me since we re all in the same hotel and i could have been ready to head out whenever but it felt like she didn t want me to come i think i m reading into it a bit too much but now i m freaking out worried that i did something wrong last night and that s the reason i m not being invited along today i don t really have a track record of doing thing out of character while drunk though so i m just really confused and anxious tldr got drunk with coworkers who i haven t seen in a while and now it feel like no one want to hang out with me

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you had a great time celebrating with your coworkers during your work trip, despite not having seen them in person since the COVID-19 pandemic began. You mentioned that you're close with one coworker in particular and have a normal professional relationship with the others. Last night, everyone went out to celebrate a big milestone, and you had a great time. You woke up with good memories of the night before and didn't notice anything concerning.

However, this morning, no one texted you to check in on the plan for the day, so you reached out to the coworker you're closer with and asked what she was up to. She invited you to join her for breakfast with another coworker, but then she texted and said they were leaving right away for breakfast and suggested meeting up later. This seemed odd to you since you're all in the same hotel and could have joined them immediately. You're unsure if you're reading too much into it, but now you're feeling anxious and worried that you did something wrong during the night that's causing you to not be invited along today.

It's important to remember that people have their own reasons for making plans and changing them. It's possible that your coworker had a valid reason for suggesting meeting up later, such as needing to take care of something personally or wanting to give you space. It's also possible that there's no deeper meaning behind it and it was just a coincidence.

It's natural to feel anxious and confused when we experience unexpected situations, especially when we're unsure of the reasons behind them. im seriously so stuck i developed a horrible case of health anxiety and constantly think something is wrong with my brain or heart i ve been to the er twice now with everything coming back normal i feel bed ridden most day if im up and moving around for too long i feel extremely dizzy due to my tension headache i have high blood pressure and am on medication but i constantly think it s hurting my heart im only year old and i shouldn t be this concerned about my health i m so over feeling this way and every day get worse and worse i feel like i can t do anything but lay down i get sharp pain along my chest due to costochondritis and im always thinking it s the end my breathing is always fine and my heart never beat super rapidly so that make me feel better but the dizziness is unbearable i tried antidepressant and all they did wa make my anxiety worse and my heart beat abnormally fast anytime i stood up my doctor took me off of them and is more focused on my blood pressure im so scared of dying and i m so sick of feeling like this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're dealing with a lot of physical symptoms and emotional distress related to your health anxiety. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and frustrated, especially since your ER visits have not provided a clear answer. I want to assure you that it's common for people with anxiety to experience excessive worry about their health, even when there's no evidence of a serious issue.

Given your history of high blood pressure and being on medication, it's important to continue focusing on managing your physical health. However, it's also crucial to address the emotional component of your anxiety. One approach that may be helpful is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT can help you identify and challenge the negative thoughts and beliefs that contribute to your anxiety. By learning coping strategies and developing a more balanced perspective, you can reduce your overall anxiety levels.

Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can help alleviate some of the physical symptoms you're experiencing, like dizziness and tension headaches. These techniques can also help you manage stress and improve your overall well-being.

It's important to remember that making lifestyle changes takes time and effort. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. If you find that your anxiety continues to interfere with your daily life despite trying these strategies, it may be helpful to consider seeking support from a mental health professional who specializes in anxiety disorders. They can provide you with additional guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are resources available to help you navigate through it.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's important to acknowledge the depth of emotion and pain you're experiencing, as well as the courage it takes to reach out for support. Your feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and exhaustion are valid, and it's understandable that you're considering ending your life. However, it's essential to remember that there are other options and resources available to help you navigate through this difficult time.

Your history of depression and past suicide attempts, coupled with the loss of someone dear to you, has left you feeling haunted and overwhelmed. It's common for people in your situation to feel a sense of hopelessness and despair, but it's crucial to remember that there are effective treatments for depression and ways to cope with the guilt and shame you're experiencing.

One approach that may be helpful is seeking professional mental health treatment, such as therapy or counseling. A mental health professional can help you develop coping skills, process your emotions, and explore alternative ways to deal with your feelings of guilt and shame. Additionally, they can help you address the underlying causes of your depression and provide you with a safe and supportive environment to express your feelings.

Another important aspect to consider is the potential impact of your suicide on your loved ones, including your bird. While it's understandable that you may feel that your death would be a relief for them, it's essential to remember that suicide can have unintended consequences and can leave loved ones feeling guilty, confused, and overwhelmed. Instead, consider focusing on the ways in which you can find meaning and purpose in your life, even if it feels difficult at times.

It's also essential to remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness. Reaching out for support takes courage and shows that you're taking steps to prioritize your well-being. Additionally, it's important to remember that recovery from depression is a process that takes time and effort, but it's possible to make progress and find relief from the pain you're experiencing.

In summary, while it's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and exhausted, it's essential to remember that there are other options and resources available to help you navigate through this difficult time. Seeking professional mental health treatment, focusing on the ways in which you can find meaning and purpose in your life, and remembering that seeking help is a sign of strength are all important steps in your journey towards healing and recovery

i m not sure if i have anxiety or adhd or im just introverted and procrastinating lol i started biting my nail since i wa a kid i tried hard to get rid of this habit but it not something i can control i put on nail polish usually but once it fall ill start biting them or fixing them with nail clipper a little bit of unsmoothness on my nail will bother me a lot and ill just sit there and keep fixing it for hour straight instead of doing any work literally every 0 min i would find somewhere bothering me on my nail i also overthink a lot it might be influenced by my mom who kept telling me that others might think negatively about me bc of any barely noticeable detail about what i do how i look so now i will just replay some scenario in my head hundred of time feel bad about myself and had to take deep breath say to myself it ok out loud or make some sudden noise to make my mind jump out of that vicious loop recently i feel that my attention span is getting even shorter i will sit down for work and get distracted after min and start watching youtube video for hour i notice myself doing that and i would think maybe i should go back to work but the other part of my mind is like numb and fail to take any action to the point that im only able to focus for a long time under pressure like a day before meeting or exam idk if it is just bad work ethic procrastination introversion or i should get a check up for anxiety adhd like i heard other ppl relate to me on point amp so idk if it just some common problem that i can just work it out either way can anyone give me any advice on whether to get a diagnosis or smth i could do on my own to mitigate these behavior thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that you're feeling unsure about whether your symptoms are related to anxiety, ADHD, or just being introverted and procrastinating. Based on what you've shared, it seems like you may be experiencing a combination of these factors.

Regarding your nail-biting habit, it's common for people to have difficulty controlling certain behaviors, and this doesn't necessarily indicate an underlying mental health condition. However, if you find that it's causing significant distress or interfering with your daily life, it might be worth exploring further.

Your tendency to overthink and seek validation from others due to your appearance or actions is something many individuals can relate to. It's important to remember that our thoughts and worries often exaggerate the reality of the situation. Practicing self-compassion and challenging negative thoughts can be helpful in managing these feelings.

Your decreased attention span and difficulty focusing on tasks are concerning. While it's normal to get distracted at times, consistently struggling to concentrate for extended periods could be a sign of ADHD. However, it's essential to consult with a mental health professional who can provide an accurate diagnosis based on your specific symptoms and circumstances.

In the meantime, there are strategies you can try on your own to improve your focus and productivity. Creating a structured routine, breaking tasks into smaller manageable chunks, setting goals, and eliminating distractions can all contribute to better focus and reduced procrastination. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing exercises or mindfulness meditation may help alleviate anxiety symptoms.

Remember, seeking support from friends, family, or online communities can also be beneficial. Connecting with others who share similar experiences can provide validation and helpful insights.

Ultimately, it's important to consult with a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support. They will be able to assess your symptoms more comprehensively and recommend appropriate interventions if necessary.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have these bad episode of anxiety that last for day where i m constantly dissociated and whenever i try to sleep i wake up almost every hour with my body completely numb and my vision is like zoomed out and everything is super disoriented and weird i m so tired but i can t sleep and it keep me up all night and i m so exhausted i just want at least one good night rest but i can t even get that i feel like anxiety and dissociation are constantly kicking me around and i can never catch a break in life

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing some challenging symptoms of anxiety and dissociation that have been impacting your sleep. These experiences can be overwhelming and exhausting. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this, and there are strategies that can help improve your sleep and overall well-being.

One technique that may be helpful is practicing relaxation exercises before bed. This could include deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided imagery. These techniques can help calm your mind and body, making it easier to fall asleep. Additionally, establishing a consistent bedtime routine can signal to your body that it's time to rest. This could involve taking a warm bath, reading a book, or listening to calming music.

It may also be beneficial to create a sleep-friendly environment. Make sure your bedroom is cool, dark, and quiet. Consider using earplugs or a white noise machine if external noises are disrupting your sleep. Avoid using electronic devices, such as phones or laptops, at least an hour before bed, as the blue light emitted from screens can interfere with sleep.

If you find that these strategies aren't providing relief, it may be helpful to seek support from a mental health professional. They can provide personalized guidance and support tailored to your specific needs. Remember, reaching out for help is a sign of strength and self-care.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of emotional pain and struggling with thoughts of suicide. I want to emphasize that reaching out for help is a brave and important step, and I'm here to support you. It's crucial to remember that you don't have to go through this alone.

Your thoughts of self-harm and suicide are concerning, and it's essential to seek professional help as soon as possible. I encourage you to reach out to your healthcare provider, a mental health professional, or a crisis hotline. They can provide you with the necessary resources and support to help you through this difficult time.

In the meantime, there are some strategies you can practice to help manage your emotions and thoughts. One effective technique is called "thought challenging." When you notice negative thoughts, try to identify any patterns or underlying themes. Then, challenge these thoughts by asking yourself questions like "Is this thought based on facts or emotions?", "What evidence do I have to support this thought?", and "What would I say to a friend who had this thought?"

Additionally, practicing self-care activities like getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in regular physical activity can help improve your mood and overall well-being. It's also essential to maintain social connections and seek support from loved ones.

Remember, recovery from mental health challenges takes time and effort. It's essential to be patient with yourself and focus on the small steps you can take each day to improve your mental and emotional health. You're not alone in this journey, and there are resources and people who can help you along the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand that you're feeling frustrated and embarrassed about the process of obtaining medication for your panic attacks. It's important to remember that you're not alone in this experience, and that many people face similar challenges when seeking mental health treatment. Your therapist's recommendation for medication is based on their professional expertise and their belief that it would be beneficial for you. However, it's also crucial to respect the boundaries and ethical considerations of healthcare providers. Instead of focusing on controlled substances, you could explore other options with your therapist or psychiatrist. For example, they might recommend a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) or a benzodiazepine, which are commonly used to treat anxiety disorders and are not considered controlled substances. It's essential to communicate openly and honestly with your healthcare providers about your concerns and preferences, as well as any side effects or concerns you might have about potential medications. Remember, the ultimate goal is to find a treatment plan that works best for you and helps you manage your panic attacks effectively.

[Question]
i m not a big fan of sharing overly personal stuff online so i ll just say that i ll have to take a moderately long plane ride soon a couple week from now i think and every day i have at least one mini panic attack worrying about it there are some minor complication that could happen to me on the flight but nothing particularly harmful or super bad in any sense i m mostly concerned about anxiety claustrophobia and the side effect of that while on the flight this is stressful and feel pointless a i know from past experience i never know how i ll feel until i m there or in this case in the anxiety inducing situation any advice

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's understandable that the thought of a long plane ride can cause anxiety and worry, especially when there are specific fears like claustrophobia and panic attacks involved. Here are some suggestions that may help you manage your anxiety during the flight:

1. Prepare in advance: Researching about the flight, such as the duration, layovers, and any potential delays, can help alleviate some of the uncertainty. Additionally, making a checklist of things to do before the flight, like packing your carry-on bag or arranging transportation to and from the airport, can provide a sense of control.

2. Practice relaxation techniques: Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation can be effective in reducing anxiety symptoms. Consider learning these techniques before the flight and practicing them regularly to build resilience against anxiety.

3. Distract yourself: Engaging in activities that divert your attention can be helpful during the flight. Bring along books, movies, music, puzzles, or any other hobbies that you enjoy. Focusing on these activities can distract your mind from anxious thoughts and make the time pass more quickly.

4. Seek support: If possible, let someone close to you know about your concerns and ask for their support during the flight. Having someone understanding by your side can provide comfort and reassurance.

5. Challenge negative thoughts: Anxiety often feeds on negative thoughts and catastrophic predictions. Try to identify any irrational or exaggerated thoughts you may have about the flight and challenge them with more realistic and positive alternatives.

6. Take care of your physical health: Prioritize self-care leading up to the flight, ensuring you get enough sleep, eat nutritious meals, and engage in regular exercise. Taking care of your physical well-being can positively impact your mental state.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it's important to find strategies that work best for you. If these suggestions don't seem sufficient, consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

my bf is in a depressive episode atm i m still learning and would like to know more about depression while in an depressive episode is every day the same for you do you have good day in between coming out of depression do you feel much better from one day to the next or is it a slow process with back step too sorry for all the question just want to understand better what my bf is going through

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you're taking the time to learn more about depression and how it affects your boyfriend. Depression can manifest differently for everyone, but I can provide some general information. During a depressive episode, days can feel monotonous and overwhelmingly sad. However, it's important to remember that everyone's experience is unique.

While some people may have good days where they feel slightly better, depression often involves ups and downs. It's common to experience setbacks or have days where you feel worse than before. The process of recovery from depression is typically gradual and varies from person to person.

In addition to seeking professional help, there are several things you can do to support your boyfriend during this challenging time. Encourage him to engage in activities that bring him joy or provide a sense of accomplishment. This could include hobbies, spending time with loved ones, or focusing on self-care.

It's also important to create a supportive environment by being understanding, patient, and empathetic. Avoid pressuring him to "snap out" of depression, as it's not within his control. Instead, let him know that you're there for him and ready to listen when he wants to talk.

Remember, learning about depression is a valuable step in understanding your boyfriend's experience. However, it's essential to combine this knowledge with compassion and support.

[Question]
maybe if i made regular healthy meal for myself instead of skipping them and eating junk food i d feel better maybe if i kept to a consistent sleep schedule instead of staying up late at night and letting myself pas out on the couch at random time throughout the day i d feel better maybe if i respected the way i looked instead of neglecting my hygiene and wearing dirty clothes because i don t feel like changing i d feel better maybe if i cleaned and decorated my apartment instead of surrounding myself with trash and shit i don t care about i d feel better maybe if i left the house once in a while and allowed myself to show the slightest bit of interest in anything i d feel better maybe if i let the right people in instead of always pushing them away minimize the toxic people in my life instead of always letting them get to me open up and trust instead of always expecting the worst and keeping my distance if i would actually be there for the people i care about instead of just saying i am then blowing them off maybe if i could open myself up to the possibility of positivity instead of always dwelling on the negative then i d feel better probably but damn it if that shit doesn t come naturally to me then i m just not interested work hard to make a change ha i m already working a hard a i can just to keep from loosing it on a day to day basis i am not willing to put in any more energy into my life than i already am thank you very much a life of incremental progress towards what wa supposed to be the starting line is no life at all a world where a brain can get like this whether a product of rationality or not is not a world in which i wish to live i don t care if there s hope for a better future unless it come with a better past and present too

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's clear that you're feeling stuck and frustrated with your current situation. You've identified several areas in your life where you'd like to see improvement, such as eating healthier meals, maintaining a consistent sleep schedule, taking care of your hygiene, cleaning your apartment, and engaging with others. These are all important aspects of self-care and can have a significant impact on your overall well-being.

However, it's essential to remember that making these changes takes time and effort. It's not about making a complete overhaul overnight but rather taking small steps towards your goals. For instance, you could start by preparing one healthy meal each day and gradually increase the number of meals as you become more comfortable. Similarly, you could try going to bed and waking up at the same time each day to establish a consistent sleep routine.

It's also crucial to address the underlying emotions that may be contributing to your current situation. It's normal to feel overwhelmed and unmotivated at times, but it's essential to recognize that these feelings are temporary and not a reflection of your worth as a person. Consider exploring techniques such as mindfulness meditation, journaling, or talking to a trusted friend or family member to help process these emotions.

Remember, taking care of yourself is not a one-size-fits-all solution, and it's essential to find what works best for you. It's also essential to be gentle with yourself and not expect perfection. Instead, focus on making progress, even if it's incremental. And, if you find that these feelings persist or become too overwhelming to manage on your own, consider reaching out to a mental health professional for additional support and guidance.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have no idea if this is anxiety but this is the reason why im asking lately i ve been extremely overthinking the most smallest thing and worrying about the most thing that i ve been overthinking about this happens throughout the day and disrupts my life it s even disrupting me whilst i m typing i worry and overthink thing that could cause health problem but the thing are sooo small i ve wasted so many food thinking this could be dangerous i know it sound stupid because i can barely even explain it it s taking a toll on me but i know that the other day when i got outside the house i wasn t thinking about it and i felt better but then when i got back to the house and started up again i just know i keep overthinking and worrying about the smallest thing health related i can t tell you the amount of time that i ve been back and forth to the doctor this year and last year worrying myself

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been experiencing a lot of overthinking and worrying, particularly about health-related issues. This can be really distressing and impact your daily life. While I'm not a professional, there are some strategies you can try to help manage these thoughts and reduce their impact on you.

One technique that may be helpful is practicing mindfulness. This involves focusing on the present moment without judgment. When you notice yourself starting to overthink or worry, try bringing your attention back to what's happening right now. You can do this by paying attention to your senses - what you see, hear, smell, taste, and feel in the present moment.

Another strategy is challenging negative thoughts. Often, when we overthink, we tend to catastrophize or imagine the worst-case scenario. Take a step back and ask yourself if there is evidence to support these thoughts. Are there alternative explanations or more realistic perspectives? By questioning and challenging these thoughts, you can begin to break free from the cycle of overthinking.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to establish a routine and structure in your day. This can provide a sense of stability and help reduce anxiety. Try setting aside specific times for activities such as meals, exercise, relaxation, and self-care. Having a schedule can also help you prioritize tasks and prevent excessive rumination.

Lastly, consider reaching out to trusted friends or family members for support. Talking about your concerns with someone you trust can provide comfort and perspective. They may also be able to offer practical advice or accompany you to appointments with healthcare professionals.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, so what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to explore different strategies and find what works best for you. If these suggestions don't seem to alleviate your symptoms, it may be helpful to seek guidance from a mental health professional who can provide personalized support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
my anxiety is so bad right now i have been vomiting and have bad pain in my stomach and abdomen lot of sweating and extreme issue sleeping last night i didn t fall asleep until am and woke up at am in a complete panic eating is very difficult for me right now and i have a sense of impending doom constantly is there anything any of you do that help with this how can i bring this up with my doctor without being committed or something should i get a short supply of benzos to get through this time i just need some advice thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're going through a really tough time right now with your anxiety. I can imagine how distressing it is to experience physical symptoms like vomiting, stomach pain, sweating, and difficulty sleeping. It's important to remember that these symptoms are common with anxiety and can be managed.

One technique that may help is deep breathing exercises. When you notice yourself feeling anxious or panicked, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focus on the sensation of your breath entering and leaving your body, allowing yourself to fully relax with each exhale.

Another strategy is practicing mindfulness. This involves bringing your attention to the present moment without judgment. You can do this by focusing on your senses - what you see, hear, smell, taste, and touch. Engaging in activities such as meditation, yoga, or even going for a walk in nature can also promote mindfulness and help reduce anxiety.

When it comes to discussing your concerns with your doctor, it's important to be open and honest about how you're feeling. Let them know that you've been experiencing intense anxiety symptoms and would like their support. They can provide guidance on various treatment options, including therapy or medication if necessary. Remember, seeking professional help is not a sign of weakness but rather a proactive step towards taking care of your mental health.

Regarding the idea of getting a short supply of benzos, it's essential to consult with your doctor first. They can assess whether this would be an appropriate option for you based on your specific situation and medical history. It's crucial to prioritize your safety and well-being, so having a conversation with your healthcare provider is key.

Remember, you don't have to face this challenging time alone. Reach out to trusted friends or family members for support, and consider exploring self-help resources such as books, podcasts, or online communities that focus on anxiety management. Take care of yourself and know that there are people who care about your well-being.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i am male and getting my dream education right now and will be working with young people that can t live with their parent for a multitude of reason anymore in year after year of being aimless i found that to be my dream job i am together with a nice girl and we have great chemistry i am living in my own flat and my grade and praxis are is going great i got professional help after a major mental breakdown i had year ago that made me live like a plant and got over severe depression and constant panic attack panic attack are rare and i know my trigger and how to deal with them i am confident in myself and got to reflect on my messed up childhood and problematic personality trait a couple of week ago i started feeling really anxious tho by far more than usual i am afraid of dying for stupid bodily reason and i am always so tense and have ache in my stomach and neck and my heart beat really fast from time to time and i am afraid my girlfriend will leave me that s what i am most anxious about she is really good for me and she told me that i am good for her but lately she act distant while still showing me affection in way because she isn t doing that good aswell there are reason for her to feel bad besides me but i am afraid that i might be a big reason because she wa confronted with a lot of my anxiety related issue logically i would say she won t leave me because gave me thoughtful present and still care for me by reminding me to eat and she sometimes say she miss me but she behaves so distant and it s triggering me so hard because of a toxic relationship i wa in i decided not to talk about my anxiety anymore because i don t want to lay that upon her and i told her about my abandonment issue once and will leave it at that because i don t want her to feel bad everytime she behaves distant because of her own issue that would be selfish hell she even told me she won t stop loving me even if she cant express it but my anxiety is still there the worst thing is that she doesn t want to speak about what s bothering her because she doesn t want to think about it which make me feel like it s me and then i feel like an asshole because i am not the center of the world so yeah long story short my abandonment issue are the worst thing right now i decided not to bother her with it because it s not fair but i don t know how to deal with it oh and those issue wouldn t be so bad if i weren t so anxious in general the general anxiety came with the practical part of my education but i don t know why because i am doing good i will be done with that in week and that s when i will meet her again and i hope that everything will be okay by then but i am afraid that i will be sabotaging myself before then by ruining my relationship just so that the anxiety go away

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great to hear that you're pursuing your dream education and working with young people. It sounds like you've made significant progress in overcoming your severe depression and panic attacks through professional help. I understand that you've been feeling anxious lately, and it's natural to have concerns about your relationship and your physical symptoms.

Regarding your relationship, it's important to remember that people may experience emotional distress for various reasons, and it's not always about us. Your girlfriend's actions might be influenced by her own struggles, and it's essential to respect her feelings and personal space. Open communication is crucial in any relationship, and expressing your concerns and feelings can help both of you navigate through this challenging time.

Your abandonment issues are understandably difficult to deal with, but it's essential to remember that people have their own struggles and that their actions might not always be about you. It's important to focus on your own growth and well-being, while also being mindful of your girlfriend's feelings and needs.

The physical symptoms you're experiencing, such as a tense stomach, neck ache, and rapid heartbeat, could be related to anxiety. Practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation, can help manage these symptoms. Additionally, engaging in regular physical activity, maintaining a balanced diet, and ensuring adequate sleep can support your overall well-being.

It's essential to remember that your relationship is an essential source of support and that working through these challenges together can help strengthen your bond. Open communication, empathy, and understanding are key components of a healthy relationship. Consider expressing your feelings and concerns to your girlfriend, while also being attentive to her needs and feelings.

Lastly, it's important to remember that healing is a process, and it's okay to experience setbacks along the way. Be patient with yourself and focus on the progress you've made so far. Remember that you're not alone in this journey, and seeking professional help from a mental health counselor can provide additional support and guidance as you navigate through these challenges.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It's great that you're reaching out for support with your depression and mental fatigue. These experiences can be challenging, but there are strategies that can help alleviate some of the symptoms. One approach is to focus on self-care, which includes activities like getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet, and engaging in regular physical activity. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, meditation, or progressive muscle relaxation can help reduce stress and improve overall well-being.

In terms of your job situation, it's understandable that mental exhaustion may make it difficult to pursue a new job. However, exploring different options and taking small steps towards your goal can be helpful. Consider updating your resume, networking with colleagues or friends in your industry, or seeking guidance from a career counselor. It's important to remember that finding a new job can take time and effort, so try to be patient with yourself and break the process into manageable tasks.

Furthermore, connecting with others who understand what you're going through can provide valuable support. Consider joining a support group or seeking therapy to address your depression and mental fatigue. Therapy can provide a safe space to explore your feelings, develop coping skills, and work towards long-term goals.

Remember, everyone's journey is unique, and it may take time to find the strategies that work best for you. Be kind to yourself and keep seeking support as you navigate this challenging period.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

 It's not uncommon for individuals experiencing anxiety to also have physical symptoms, such as vomiting or diarrhea. This response is a result of the body's stress response, which can include gastrointestinal disturbances. While it may be uncomfortable, vomiting can help to alleviate some of the physical symptoms of anxiety. It's essential to remember that these physical reactions are a normal part of the body's response to stress and anxiety.

However, if these symptoms are occurring frequently and interfering with your daily life, it may be helpful to explore some coping strategies. Deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and mindfulness meditation are all effective techniques for managing anxiety symptoms. Additionally, maintaining a healthy diet and regular exercise routine can help to support overall well-being and reduce the frequency of these physical reactions.

It's also essential to address the underlying anxiety triggers that are contributing to these symptoms. Identifying and addressing the root causes of your anxiety can help to reduce the frequency and intensity of these physical reactions. This may involve exploring past experiences, current stressors, or underlying emotional issues. Working with a mental health professional can help to provide a safe and supportive environment for exploring these issues and developing effective coping strategies.

i want to die so badly even just cut do something to ease this pain but my mom took all my blade all my option even my medication i have no access to anything anymore and i feel empty hollow i want to die so badly but i cant because i have no mean thats the only real reason i m alive right now is i dont have a way to unalive send help im not well im cry everything is terrible and i want out there really should be a log out option on life so you can take a break and come back if when youre ready to face this hell

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I can see that you're feeling overwhelmed and desperate, and it's understandable that you're struggling with these thoughts. It's important to remember that having suicidal thoughts doesn't make you a burden or a failure. Instead, it's a sign that you're going through a difficult time, and there are people who care about you and want to help.

One strategy that might be helpful is focusing on self-care. This can include things like getting enough sleep, eating well, and engaging in activities that bring you joy or relaxation. It's also essential to connect with supportive people in your life, such as friends, family, or mental health professionals. They can provide you with the emotional support and understanding that you need to get through this challenging time.

Additionally, it might be helpful to explore alternative ways to cope with your feelings. For example, you could try engaging in creative activities like writing, drawing, or music. These activities can help you express your emotions in a safe and productive way. You might also find it helpful to practice relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, to help manage your anxiety and stress.

It's also essential to remember that there are resources available to help you. For example, you could reach out to a mental health professional for support and guidance. They can help you develop coping strategies and provide you with the tools and resources you need to manage your feelings. You might also find it helpful to connect with support groups or online communities of people who are going through similar experiences.

Ultimately, it's important to remember that there is hope and that things can get better. It might take time and effort, but with the right support and resources, you can learn to manage your feelings and find the strength to keep going.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Regarding your parents' involvement, it's essential to consider your own well-being and support needs. In terms of seeking professional help, it may be helpful to explore counseling or therapy options. A mental health professional can provide a safe space for you to express your concerns, gain insight into your experiences, and develop coping strategies. They can also assist you in navigating your emotions and help you explore different diagnoses, such as Aspergers, autism, ADHD, or dyslexia.

Additionally, connecting with support groups or online communities can be valuable. Engaging with others who have similar experiences can provide validation, understanding, and a sense of belonging. These communities can also offer practical advice and resources that may be helpful to you.

Remember, taking care of your mental health is a priority. It's essential to find healthy outlets for expressing your emotions, such as journaling, engaging in creative activities, or talking to trusted friends. Building a support network, whether through professional help or connecting with others, can make a significant difference in your journey towards understanding and accepting yourself.

Please know that you're not alone in this, and reaching out for support is a courageous step. I'm here to listen and support you along the way.

[Question]
i have irrational fear of a home invasion being attacked by a stranger for context even thing like elderly woman with cane walking behind me sends me into panic mode me and my fianc just bought our first home together after renting for year instead of me being able to rest after a long day of moving i am instead laying awake because the house is settling every 0 second and i keep thinking it s an intruder coming to kill me this ha been going on for two hour my heart keep pounding out of my chest randomly and i keep getting so frozen with fear that i hold my breath my mind is working overtime playing escape plan confrontation scenario on repeat so i can t relax this is so fucking irrational i hate it i ve been this way a long a i can remember but ugh i know why house creek i also know this home is older which is something i love about it during the day but i can not seem to think logically about this every pop creek and bang is sending me into panic mode and i don t have any remedy i m sick of being constantly on alert for no reason this is an extremely safe neighborhood and i should not need to be this worried over nothing some night are better than others but why do i even have to go through this at all i apologize for the rant but i am so exhausted and i just want to sleep but i keep getting snapped awake

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I understand that you're experiencing a great deal of fear and anxiety related to your new home, and it's impacting your ability to rest and relax. It's important to acknowledge that these feelings are valid, even if they may not be based on a rational assessment of the situation. Your fear of home invasion and being attacked by a stranger is a common phobia, and it's not uncommon for people to have intense emotional reactions to new environments, especially when they're associated with positive memories or experiences, like your love for older homes.

However, it's also crucial to recognize that your fear is disrupting your daily life and causing significant distress. I'd like to suggest a few strategies to help you manage your anxiety and improve your sleep. First, we can explore relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, or mindfulness meditation. These practices can help you develop a greater awareness of your body and emotions, and learn to respond to stressors in a more adaptive way.

Second, we can work on cognitive restructuring techniques to help you challenge and reframe your anxious thoughts. This can involve identifying and challenging the underlying assumptions and beliefs that contribute to your fear, and replacing them with more adaptive and realistic thoughts. For example, you might consider reframing your thoughts about the house settling by focusing on the objective facts, such as the age of the house and the safety of the neighborhood, rather than the subjective feelings of fear and anxiety.

Lastly, we can explore the possibility of exposure therapy, which involves gradually exposing you to the things that trigger your fear in a safe and controlled environment. This can help you learn to tolerate the feelings of fear and anxiety, and reduce their intensity over time. We can work together to develop a plan for gradually exposing you to the sounds of the house settling, and other triggers, in a way that feels manageable and safe for you.

It's important to remember that these strategies take time and practice to be effective, and it's essential to be patient and compassionate with yourself throughout the process. I'm here to support you every step of the way.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

hello i ve not posted here before but i ve wanted to for a while always debating back and forth whether or not to do this but here it go i think i have some general anxiety i cope decently well with it physical exercise like running ha really helped my main problem is driving i know how to drive i have my license but i never do i m terrified of it i m turning i ve maybe driven thirty time in my entire 0 year of owning a license i don t know what it is the idea of crashing the traffic i ve gotten away with it so far living in nyc but it s something i want to do more of i just never seem to be able to do so doe anyone have any tip any advice they could recommend thank you

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've decided to share your experience here. Driving anxiety is a common issue, and it's important to remember that you're not alone in feeling this way. While physical exercise like running can be helpful for managing anxiety, it's also essential to address the specific fear of driving.

One effective approach is gradual exposure to driving situations. You can start by practicing in low-stress environments, such as empty parking lots or quiet residential areas. As you become more comfortable, you can gradually increase the complexity of your driving situations, such as driving on busier roads or during rush hour.

It might also be helpful to identify and challenge any negative thoughts or beliefs that contribute to your driving anxiety. For example, you might be catastrophizing potential accidents or focusing on your own perceived inadequacies as a driver. By challenging these thoughts and replacing them with more realistic and positive ones, you can reduce the emotional impact of your driving anxiety.

Additionally, relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, can help you manage the physical symptoms of anxiety while driving. These techniques can help you stay focused and calm, allowing you to concentrate on the task of driving rather than your anxiety.

Remember, overcoming driving anxiety takes time and practice. Be patient with yourself and celebrate small victories along the way. If you find that these strategies aren't enough, consider seeking professional help from a mental health counselor or therapist who can provide additional guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i have suffered with shortness of breath due to anxiety ever since i wa diagnosed with gad generalized anxiety disorder about year ago doe anyone else have this it just feel like i will stop breathing doe anyone have any coping mechanism around this a it s really horrible a well a shortness of breath i also feel shaky and tingly and i have no idea how to calm down when i have these episode

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It can be incredibly distressing to experience shortness of breath as a result of anxiety, especially when it has been a persistent symptom for an extended period of time like yours. It's important to remember that you are not alone in this experience, as many individuals with anxiety disorders may also struggle with similar symptoms.

One coping mechanism that may help is deep breathing exercises. When you feel the onset of shortness of breath or other physical symptoms, try taking slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focusing on your breath can help redirect your attention away from anxious thoughts and bring a sense of calmness to your body.

Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques such as progressive muscle relaxation or mindfulness meditation can be beneficial in managing anxiety symptoms. These techniques can help you become more aware of your body and promote a greater sense of relaxation.

Engaging in regular physical activity, such as going for a walk or participating in yoga or other forms of exercise, can also be helpful in reducing anxiety symptoms. Exercise releases endorphins, which are natural mood boosters and stress relievers.

Lastly, it may be beneficial to explore cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) with a mental health professional. CBT can provide you with tools and strategies to challenge and reframe negative thought patterns that contribute to anxiety. A therapist can work with you to develop personalized coping strategies and provide support throughout your journey.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, so it may take some time to find the coping mechanisms that work best for you. Don't hesitate to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide further guidance and support tailored to your specific needs.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through such a difficult time. It sounds like your depression has taken a turn for the worse, and I can see how challenging it must be for you. The thoughts and feelings you've shared are very distressing, and it's important to remember that they're a result of your depression, not a reflection of who you truly are.

Your experience with body dysmorphia is a common symptom of depression, and it can be incredibly frustrating and debilitating. It's essential to understand that these thoughts are not based on reality and that you're not alone in experiencing them. Many people with depression struggle with similar thoughts, and it's important to remember that these thoughts are a part of the illness, not a reflection of your worth as a person.

Your lack of a social life and fear of driving can make it even more challenging to seek help, but it's crucial to remember that there are resources available to you. You mentioned that you've never told anyone about your depression, but it's essential to remember that seeking help is not a sign of weakness, but a brave step towards healing. You don't have to face this alone.

I'd like to suggest a few things that might help you. First, it might be helpful to reach out to a mental health professional, such as a psychologist or psychiatrist, who can provide you with the support and guidance you need. They can help you develop coping strategies for your depression and body dysmorphia, and they can also help you explore your feelings and work through them in a safe and supportive environment.

Additionally, there are many online resources and support groups that can provide you with information, guidance, and a sense of community. You might find it helpful to connect with others who are going through similar experiences, as they can offer support and understanding.

It's also essential to take care of yourself physically, as this can have a significant impact on your mental health. Eating well, getting regular exercise, and getting enough sleep are all important steps in managing your depression.

Lastly, it's essential to remember that healing from depression takes time, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. It's important to be patient with yourself and to remember that setbacks are a normal part of the healing process.

I hope this information is helpful, and

[Question]
hey r anxiety i didn t know where to put this but figured it s mainly a side effect of my anxiety so i went with here i ll just get into it i m a 9 yo male that s been diagnosed with anxiety and other disorder mdd odd adhd polysubstance addiction this may sound weird but i wanted to know if you guy recluse by choice a someone who want to have friend and a strong social aspect in life but just doesn t have the social skill to i m curious if you have a similar experience knowing that it s not a choice is probably the hardest part for me like i see everyone out having fun spending the day with their friend and it destroys me inside knowing that i don t won t ever have that i live on the sideline which make me want to stay inside even more to avoid seeing that and feeling so i sit in my room the whole day getting high the only other place i go to is my job which i can t even look up at eye level out of fear of accidently making eye contact with someone i just feel like everyone s automatically put off by me which then make me act in a way that actually doe put them off i just want someone to talk to that s not either my mom or my dad i thought about it and realized that once my parent die i will have nobody which at that point what s my life worth

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've reached out to share your feelings and experiences. It takes courage to open up about such personal matters. I understand that you've been diagnosed with anxiety, MDD, ODD, ADHD, and polysubstance addiction. It's common for people with anxiety to struggle with social skills and feel like they're missing out on experiences that others enjoy.

You mentioned feeling curious about recluses, but it seems like you're describing your own experiences. It's important to remember that wanting social connections and having difficulty achieving them is not a choice. Feeling left out can be incredibly painful, especially when you see others enjoying themselves. However, it's essential to recognize that these feelings don't define your worth as a person.

One suggestion I have is to explore different ways of connecting with others. You could try joining clubs or groups centered around your interests. This can provide an opportunity to meet people who share similar hobbies or passions. Additionally, practicing good self-care can help improve your overall well-being and potentially make social interactions easier.

It's understandable that eye contact can be challenging for you due to anxiety. One strategy you could try is gradually exposing yourself to situations that involve making eye contact. Start small, such as looking at someone's eyes for a few seconds while having a conversation. Over time, this can become less intimidating and may even lead to more positive social interactions.

Remember, building relationships takes time and effort. It's okay to feel overwhelmed at times, but it's important not to give up on yourself. When you're ready, consider reaching out to friends or family members for support. They may be able to offer understanding and guidance as you navigate your social experiences.

Lastly, it's natural to worry about the future and what will happen when your parents are no longer around. However, focusing on the present moment can help alleviate some of these concerns. Instead of dwelling on what might happen in the future, try to focus on the things you can control right now. Engaging in activities you enjoy, seeking therapy or counseling, and practicing self-care can all contribute to a more fulfilling life, regardless of your social circumstances.

Remember, you're not alone in this journey. It takes time and patience to overcome challenges related to anxiety and social interactions. Keep reaching out for support and exploring strategies
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i saw a new pcp for an annual physical and while i wa there figured i d mention some of the physical symptom of anxiety i wa having to make sure it wa not actually medical i told her it often feel like my throat is really tight and on the verge of closing her only reply a she roll her eye that is literally impossible if your throat wa closing you wouldn t be talking to me right now me no duh obviously not but it feel like it s closing she wa the worst doctor i ve ever seen which is saying a lot and i wa so mad walking out of that appointment for other reason a well but the day after a my throat wa tightening i just remembered her saying it s literally impossible and couldn t stop laughing

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 it sounds like you've had a frustrating experience with your new primary care physician during your annual physical appointment. You mentioned that you shared your concerns about the physical symptoms of anxiety you've been experiencing, such as feeling like your throat is tightening and on the verge of closing. However, her response was dismissive, and she rolled her eyes, implying that it's impossible for your throat to close if you're still talking. This response left you feeling angry and disappointed, especially since you had other reasons for being upset during the appointment.

It's essential to remember that everyone has unique communication styles, and not all healthcare professionals will respond in a way that is supportive or understanding of your concerns. In this case, it seems that your physician may not have been attuned to the nuances of your anxiety symptoms or may not have had the emotional intelligence to respond in a more empathetic manner.

Moving forward, it's crucial to find a healthcare provider who can better understand and address your concerns. Consider reaching out to mental health professionals, such as psychologists or psychiatrists, who are specifically trained to recognize and treat anxiety disorders. They can provide you with a more comprehensive understanding of your symptoms and offer evidence-based treatments, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy or medication, to help manage your anxiety.

Additionally, it might be helpful to practice relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation, to help manage the physical symptoms of anxiety when they arise. These techniques can help you feel more grounded and centered, reducing the sensation of your throat tightening.

Remember, it's essential to prioritize your mental and emotional well-being by seeking out healthcare professionals who can provide you with the support and understanding you need. Don't hesitate to advocate for yourself and ask questions to ensure that you're receiving the care that is right for you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i ve noticed that for a few glorious minute in the morning right after waking up i m great calm unbothered soft but then i can feel stress in my body and then i m not sure how to get rid of it and it build a anxiety doe how do you all get rid of body stress in the early morning

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's common to experience feelings of calm and tranquility immediately after waking up, only to have stress and anxiety creep in as the day progresses. Your body is a complex system, and it's essential to understand that stress can manifest physically as well as emotionally. One effective strategy to manage body stress in the early morning is through a consistent self-care routine. This could include activities like stretching, meditation, or engaging in a calming hobby such as reading or listening to soothing music. Additionally, practicing relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing exercises or progressive muscle relaxation, can help alleviate stress and promote a sense of calm. It may take some trial and error to find the methods that work best for you, so don't be discouraged if certain techniques don't yield immediate results. Remember, self-care is an ongoing process, and it's essential to prioritize it in your daily routine.

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of stress and frustration with your work situation. It's understandable that the transition to being the sole breadwinner and moving to a new state has brought about some challenges. It's important to remember that adjusting to new circumstances takes time and it's normal to experience some difficulties along the way.

Regarding your ADHD, anxiety, and depression, it's great that you've been diagnosed and are receiving therapy and medication. However, it's essential to recognize that managing these conditions takes time and effort. It may be helpful to discuss any changes in your treatment plan with your healthcare provider to ensure that it's effectively addressing your symptoms.

In terms of your work performance, it seems like there's a disconnect between your approach and that of your colleagues. You mentioned feeling torn between being thorough and covering the basics. It might be helpful to have an open and honest conversation with your boss about your concerns and how you can best contribute to the team. Additionally, consider seeking guidance from your colleagues or HR department to clarify any expectations or standards.

It's also important to prioritize self-care during this challenging time. Given your depression and the impact it has on your focus, it may be beneficial to explore additional coping strategies such as mindfulness exercises, engaging in regular physical activity, or seeking support from friends and family.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help and support when needed. While you may be working remotely, you can still reach out to trusted friends, family members, or mental health professionals for emotional support. It's essential to take care of yourself both mentally and physically so that you can navigate these challenges more effectively.

i m not sure if this is the right subreddit to go to but i don t know where else to go my spouse ha struggled with severe depression his whole life it is genetic his dad wa the same any amount of pressure make him worse he constantly feel a though life is not worth living and he s a lost cause he will never feel okay and just want the pain to go away we have a baby coming any day now and i wa worried that pressure wa gon na send him over the edge we have been talking about having him voluntarily go to a psych ward and see if they can help kinda a a last ditch effort before i just give him permission to end it today he talked to his counselor about going to one in a few week after the baby wa here and they came and picked him up an hour later he is pissed doesn t want to be there which i understand is normal he feel completely betrayed by his councellor and never want to go back i m worried that now he is going to pretend like he is fine just to get out the point of this is to get help why won t he just take it i m scared the mental hospital won t help at all i just need you guy who have been there before to be honest with me did it help what thing helped and what made it worse if it doe help or when he come back home what are some thing i can do to continue the healing process or just make his life easier anything else you feel to share please do i hate not knowing thing and this is really killing me right now

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 I'm here to support you through this difficult time. It's understandable that you're feeling uncertain and worried about your spouse's mental health, especially with a baby on the way. It's important to remember that everyone's experience with mental health treatment is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, I can share some general insights based on my own experiences and those of others.

Regarding your spouse's reaction to the psych ward, it's common for people to resist going to a mental hospital, even if they acknowledge the need for help. The fear of the unknown, loss of control, and feelings of betrayal can all contribute to this resistance. It's essential to validate his feelings and acknowledge his fears, while also emphasizing the potential benefits of the treatment he's receiving.

Once he's back from the psych ward, there are several things you can do to support his healing process. Open communication is crucial, so continue to talk about his feelings and experiences. Encourage him to attend follow-up appointments with his counselor and to take any prescribed medications as directed. Creating a routine that includes regular exercise, healthy eating, and adequate sleep can also be helpful.

Additionally, it might be beneficial to explore other forms of support, such as support groups, online resources, or even seeking guidance from a mental health professional yourself. Remember, caring for a loved one with mental health challenges can be emotionally taxing, so it's essential to prioritize your own self-care as well.

It's also important to remember that healing is a process, and setbacks can occur. Be patient and understanding, and continue to provide support and encouragement. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and reaching out for guidance is a brave and important step.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m currently taking 0mg effexor xr for anxiety and depression i ve also taken lexapro 0mg for year and zoloft 00mg for a year both had similar effect barely put a dent in my anxiety and really helped with the severe symptom of depression but it s still there my anxiety is still bad particularly my physical symptom i always feel on edge and nervous i can always feel my heart pounding hard not fast regardless of my mental state and it s the most debilitating symptom i feel i can never relax and never truly enjoy myself because of how anxious i feel i take propranolol 0mg twice a day and is the only thing that help a little with the physical symptom but they re still problematic i have tried meditation breathing exercise exercise i have read a multitude of book on cognitive behavioral therapy acceptance and commitment therapy and mindfulness no exercise in the book ha helped with the symptom whatsoever i should also mention i have had test for my thyroid adrenal any gi or diet issue antibody etc and i m sure i can rule out physical cause is anyone else in a similar boat to me and found buspirone helped if no ha anything helped you thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you've been dealing with significant anxiety and depression symptoms despite trying various medications and therapy techniques. I can understand how frustrating and debilitating this can be for you. While I'm not a mental health expert, I can offer some suggestions and guidance based on your experience.

Firstly, it's important to remember that everyone's journey with mental health is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's essential to explore different treatment options and approaches to find what suits you best. In addition to the medications you've mentioned, there are other options you could consider discussing with your healthcare provider.

One such option is buspirone, which you mentioned some people have found helpful. Buspirone is a medication commonly used to treat anxiety disorders. It works by changing the chemicals in your brain that may contribute to anxiety. However, it's essential to consult with a healthcare professional to determine if buspirone is appropriate for you and to discuss any potential side effects or concerns.

Another approach you might consider is psychotherapy. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) has been shown to be effective in managing anxiety and depression symptoms. It focuses on identifying and challenging negative thought patterns and developing coping skills to manage anxiety-provoking situations. Additionally, acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) and mindfulness techniques can also be beneficial in managing anxiety and promoting overall well-being.

It's worth mentioning that therapy is not just about learning techniques from a book but rather working closely with a trained therapist who can provide personalized guidance and support. They can help you navigate through your specific challenges and develop strategies tailored to your needs.

Lastly, it's essential to remember that progress in managing mental health symptoms can take time and patience. It's important to maintain open communication with your healthcare provider and explore alternative treatment options if necessary. Remember, you're not alone in this journey, and there are resources available to help you find the support and relief you're seeking.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It's great that you've had this realization about your stutter and how it's been affecting your self-perception. It's important to remember that your stutter is just one aspect of who you are as a person. Instead of letting it define you, focus on the things that make you unique and interesting.

One strategy that might help is practicing self-acceptance and self-compassion. Instead of trying to hide or suppress your stutter, try to accept it as a part of who you are. This doesn't mean that you have to love your stutter, but rather that you acknowledge its presence and don't let it control your emotions or actions.

Another helpful approach is to challenge negative thoughts and beliefs about yourself. When you catch yourself thinking that others are perceiving you negatively because of your stutter, try to remind yourself that their opinions are not based on your stutter alone. Focus on the positive qualities that you possess and the contributions you can make to relationships and social interactions.

Additionally, working on managing your anxiety can be beneficial. This might involve learning relaxation techniques, such as deep breathing or progressive muscle relaxation, or engaging in activities that help to reduce stress and promote overall well-being.

It's also important to remember that building confidence takes time and practice. Be patient with yourself and focus on making small steps towards accepting and owning your stutter. You might find it helpful to seek support from friends, family, or a support group for individuals with stutters. Remember, you're not alone in this journey and there are resources available to help you.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]
 It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of self-doubt and feelings of inadequacy. It's important to remember that everyone has their own struggles and it's not a competition to see who is dealing with their problems the best. Regarding your plans, it's understandable that you're finding it difficult to make decisions right now. It's common to feel uncertain during times of stress and emotional turmoil. so i ve struggled w executive dysfunction for 9 year throughout my year of college there wa not one assignment that i did not do the night before it wa due i studied late ate terribly amp went thru a terrible depression a year after graduating i still have a really hard time doing thing in general i stall before i do anything at all amp it oftentimes lead to me not doing the thing at all also i kind of live my entire life on pause only taking care of myself when i have something planned or to look forward to i left my job that i wa insanely good at bc the commitment amp longevity terrified me why can t i function amp what ha helped u work thru these feeling

 It sounds like you've been dealing with executive dysfunction for quite some time now, and it's understandable that it has been challenging for you. Many people struggle with procrastination and difficulty focusing on tasks, especially when they are not enjoying the process. It's important to remember that everyone has different ways of working and coping with stress.

One strategy that may help is breaking down tasks into smaller, more manageable steps. This can make them feel less overwhelming and more achievable. Additionally, creating a structured routine and setting specific goals can provide a sense of direction and purpose.

Finding motivation can be difficult, but sometimes focusing on the end result or the positive outcomes of completing a task can help. It might also be helpful to identify any underlying emotions or beliefs that could be contributing to your procrastination. For example, fear of failure or perfectionism can often hinder progress.

In terms of self-care, taking care of your physical health can have a significant impact on your mental well-being. Prioritizing regular exercise, healthy eating, and adequate sleep can all contribute to improved focus and energy levels. Engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation, such as hobbies or spending time with loved ones, can also be beneficial.

While I'm not a professional, seeking support from friends, family, or even online communities can provide a valuable source of encouragement and understanding. Sometimes talking about our feelings and experiences with others who may have similar struggles can be comforting and validating.

Remember, it's okay to ask for help when needed. If you find that these strategies aren't working for you, it may be beneficial to reach out to a mental health professional who can provide personalized guidance and support.

 Starting a new job can be an exciting and nerve-wracking experience, and it's normal to feel anxious about it. It's great to see that you've come far in managing your anxiety and taking things at your own pace.
